Gauge fixing eliminates 13 degrees of freedom, reducing (24,2) → (12,1). The physical content projects onto a 13-dimensional shadow spacetime with one effective time direction. The 12 surviving spatial dimensions define the orientation sum parameter that appears in proton decay and gravitational wave predictions (see Appendix H).

Following Bars' two-time physics formalism, the Sp(2,ℝ) gauge symmetry imposes three fundamental constraints on phase space coordinates (X^M, P^M) with M = 0, 1, ..., 25 and metric signature η_{MN} = diag(-1, -1, +1, ..., +1) for (24,2):

content_blocks.description: Orthogonality constraint between position and momentum

content_blocks.content: These constraints are first-class in the Dirac sense, forming a closed constraint algebra under Poisson brackets. They eliminate exactly 13 degrees of freedom through gauge fixing, reducing the 26-dimensional phase space to a physical 13-dimensional configuration space.
Initial phase space: 52 DOF total (26 positions X^M + 26 momenta P^M)

Three first-class constraints: X^2 = 0, X · P = 0, P^2 = M^2. In Dirac formalism, each first-class constraint removes 2 phase space DOF: (1) 1 DOF from constraint surface itself; (2) 1 DOF from gauge orbit (Sp(2,ℝ) transformation). Total: 3 × 2 = 6 phase space DOF removed
Sp(2,ℝ) gauge generators: L_0 = (1/2)X^2, L_1 = X · P, L_{-1} = (1/2)P^2. Form SL(2,ℝ) algebra with 3 parameters; complete gauge fixing removes 3 additional DOF
Phase space → configuration space: Physical DOF = (phase space DOF)/2. From 52 - 6 - 3 = 43 → ~22 configuration DOF after constraints
Temporal gauge fixing: X^+ = τ, P^+ = E fixes remaining gauge freedom. This eliminates one time coordinate entirely, projecting (24,2) → (12,1)
Result: The net effect halves the configuration space: 26 → 13 physical dimensions. Note: The exact counting depends on gauge choice; all consistent gauges yield 13D shadow

content_blocks.title: Physical Interpretation: Why Two Times Don't Cause Problems

content_blocks.content: The (24,2) signature might naively suggest two independent time directions leading to causality violations and ghost states. The Sp(2,ℝ) constraints prevent this:

items.label: Null constraint
items.content: X^2 = 0 links the two times to spatial dimensions via -t_1^2 - t_2^2 + |\vec{x}|^2 = 0

items.label: Mass-shell
items.content: P^2 = M^2 ensures positive energy via Einstein dispersion

items.label: Effective single time
items.content: After gauge fixing, only one linear combination of (t_1, t_2) appears in observables—the "thermal time" in the 13D shadow

content_blocks.content: Key insight: the constraints don't eliminate one time by compactification, but enforce that the two times are gauge-related, projecting to a single physical time through the constraint surface.

The 4-brane structure (1 observable + 3 shadow) provides a geometric explanation for quantum apparent randomness. Observable states on our brane Σ_1 result from partial tracing over shadow brane degrees of freedom:

content_blocks.content: What appears as quantum randomness is actually deterministic dynamics across the full 4-brane system, with apparent stochasticity arising from our inability to access shadow sector states.

This hidden variable structure evades Bell's theorem because Bell constrains local hidden variables. The inter-brane correlations are fundamentally non-local in 3D space: the Pneuma field propagates through the bulk, coupling all branes non-locally via extra dimensions. What appears non-local in 3D is actually local in the 26D bulk geometry.
Pre-measurement: Observable and shadow branes are entangled via bulk Pneuma field
Measurement: Decoherence with macroscopic apparatus on Σ_1
Outcome: Determined by shadow brane state (the "hidden variable")
Apparent collapse: Just learning about pre-existing bulk correlation

note.content: Randomness is epistemic (our ignorance of shadow branes), not ontic (fundamental indeterminacy). This restores determinism at the 26D bulk level. See simulations/hidden_variables_v12_8.py.
